body.p: Был доктор Тейльс, котораго дети и внуки у нас и ныне. Сей, быв в Царьграде в 1716 г. и до того у Голандскаго посла, вел негоциации Петра I, когда Шафиров и Толстой сидели в семи башнях. После того сей Тейльс обнародовал на французском языке в малой книжке свои негоциации. Сия книжка в моей вивлиофике была, но не знаю, не отдала ли я ее графу Безбородку. Прошу ее отыскать. Буде отъищите, отдайте ее на прочтение графу Сегюру.Khrapovitsky noted in his diary on 7 January 1789: 'Показывали, что во вчерашний день прочтена половина книги доктора Тейлса. Тут невыгодна негоциация Петра I-го: c'est la nécessité des circonstances' ('[She] showed me that yesterday she read half of doctor Theyls's book. Peter I's negotiation is not advantageous here: it is the necessity of the circumstances'). On 10 January, he noted: 'Читают Тейлса, и взнесены книги о разных негоциациях, по отметке в каталоге Вейтбрехта' ('She is reading Theyls, and books about various negotiations have been brought in according to Weitbrecht's catalogue'); on 11 January, 'Отданы для сообщения Гр. Сегюру на прочтение: 'Mémoires pour servir à l'histoire de Charles XII', par W. Theyls; à Leyde. 1722, и приказано отыскать, в библиотеке, посольства: de Mr. du Frêne Canaye, du Prèsident [sic] Jeannin, de Mr d'Angoulème [sic], de Bassompièrre [sic], du Cardinal du Perron, du Cardinal d'Ossat, de Paul de Foix, de Mr. d'Estrade, de Montluc, et de Villeroi.--Je suis à présent dans la politique, никогда за эти книги не принималась' ('She gave me the 'Memoirs to serve for the history of Charles XII', by W. Theyls; Leiden, 1722, and ordered me to find in the library the embassies of Mr. du Frêne Canaye, the President Jeannin, d'Angloulème, Bassompièrre, the Cardinal du Perron, the Cardinal d'Ossat, Paul de Foix, d'Estrade, Montluc, and Villeroi.--I am now in politics [diplomacy], I never before taken up these books'). (Dnevnik A.V. Khrapovitskago 1782-1793, pp. 229, 231-32,). Another note to Khrapovitsky, also dated 6 January 1789, bears the laconic indication: 'Об отсылке к гр. Сегюру книги доктора Тейльса' ('About sending doctor Theyls's book to Count Ségur') ('Sobstvennoruchnyya pisma i zapiski Imperatritsy Ekateriny II-i k A.V. Khrapovitskomu, 1783-1793', column 2085). In the Treaty of Pruth, Peter I was forced to surrender his claims to lands conquered from the Ottomans (Azov) and to domination in Poland, in the face of war against both the Ottoman Empire and Sweden. Catherine could not have missed the parallel with her own situation: at this time she faced war against the Ottomans and the Swedes, while the Prussians were stirring up opposition to Russia in Poland. In true eighteenth-century style, she turned to past examples to help her find her way in this difficult diplomatic situation. Ségur at the time was negotiating (unsuccessfully) a four-way alliance between Russia, Austria, France, and Spain, and enjoying close converse with the empress.

There was a Doctor Theyls, whose children and grandchildren still live here. This man, being in Tsargrad [Istanbul] in 1716 and before that with the Dutch ambassador, carried on Peter I's negotiations when Shafirov and Tolstoy were imprisoned in the seven towers. Afterward this Theyls published his negotiations in French in a little book. This little book was in my library, but I do not know if I gave it to Count Bezborodko. Please find it. If you find it, give it to Count Ségur to read.
